Definitions of current and charge
...

We know that current in a circuit is the flow of electrons in a circuit (per unit time). We can represent this in an equation with the following equation:
But this is clearly equivalent to the following:
In other words, we can mathematically represent the circuit as if many protons were moving in the opposite direction of the electron flow. This is conventional current, or hole current. Normally, we use conventional current rather than electron flow.

Charge is normally denoted by . Its unit is the Coulomb, C, and is quantizable. Charge is some multiple of the electron charge constant, either positive of negative. The electron charge constant is:

If we want to avoid the use of "electrons" in terms of current, we can just say that current is the the rate of flow electric charge (past a given point) per unit time. In other words,

The unit of current is the ampere, or one coulomb per second. If the current is known, the charge at some time is calculated by summing the charge at with the integral from 0 to of .

Current notation with arrows
...

One thing to note is that drawing a current to the left and labeling it 10 A is the same thing as drawing a current to the right and labeling it -10 A. This also means that drawing a current to the right and labeling it 10 A is not the same thing as either of those two circuits.

The important thing to note here is that a minus sign on a current arrow indicates that the current is opposite of the arrow direction.

Examples: integral of charge, derivative of current
...

DC currents and AC currents
...

There are two kinds of currents - direct and alternating. We will mostly deal with DC circuits, which is to say that it outputs a current of constant magnitude. An AC current is a time-varying current where is not equal to a constant, but some function in terms of . It may be a ramp (linear), sinusoid, exponential, etc. The most common is sinusoidal.

Of note is that AC currents are generally considered to be more efficient than DC currents.

The first eight chapters are DC circuits. The final chapter, Chapter 10, is adapting DC techniques to AC circuits.

Resistance
...

Say we go back to our water in a pipe. There's a piece of gum stuck inside the pipes. The water that flows past the piece of gum is equivalent to the water flowing before the gum - it's not like there's less water because of the gum. But in striking the gum, the water loses a non-zero amount of energy.

Likewise, in a circuit, shoving current through a resistor in a series circuit causes it to have a lower potential energy after the resistor. Since the charge hasn't disappeared, current is constant. But voltage is not constant, since there exists a potential difference across the resistor.

Convention says that the positive terminal has higher electric potential and the negative terminal has lower potential.

Remember from Kirchoff's laws that if we follow a certain direction, we add or subtract energy from the circuit. So if we go from high to low potential, entering the positive terminal and leaving from the negative terminal, this (could be) a resistor which absorbs energy. Anything that absorbs energy is a passive element.

Likewise, if it goes from low to high potential, it is an energy source, like a battery. We refer to this as an active element.

Voltage
...

Depending on the diagram you see, we can say that if the current passes from high potential (a) to low potential (b) with a difference of 5 volts, we say that the voltage drop from a to b is 5 volts. If the current runs in the opposite direction, then we say the voltage rise from b to a is 5 volts.

Simply put, the voltage between a to b is the derivative of work (in Joules) as a function of charge. It is the ratio of to , or:

Note that one volt is equal to 1 Joule per Coulomb, where 1 Joule is the energy required to move electrons across a resistive element.

Something else to note is that voltage is relative, not absolute. It's called a potential difference because you need to take the difference of two things.

Passive sign convention
...

When the current enters the circuit at the positive terminal and exits at the negative terminal, the voltage and current are said to adhere to the passive convention. In engineering terms, we say that the flow is "natural" - things normally go from high to low energy without putting any additional work in.

But you need to put work in to cause the energy to increase. Thus, we call such elements active, since it is not "natural" for a circuit element to passively cause energy to increase. If a current enters low potential and exits with high potential, it does not adhere to passive sign convention, since the voltage will increase.

If the direction of the current relative to the potentials at each end of an element adhere to the passive convention, the power is the power absorbed/received by the element.

If it does not adhere to the passive convention, the power (the same equation) is the power supplied/delivered by the element.

Power
...

Power is the time rate of supplying or receiving energy (work), or joules per second. Its unit is the Watt, and its equations are:
In other words, power is the derivative of work with respect to time.

(Looks like the chain rule for implicit differentiation in multivariable calculus.)

Given the function for work, you can get the value for work at any given value of time.
(Note that formally, this has as its lower bound as well; but we can assume that the element only receives power for and let .)

Examples: power, current, and passive convention
...

Example

Find the power in an element where the current goes from high potential to low potential (positive to negative), where V = 5V and I = 10A.

Using , the power is 50 watts. Since this element adheres to passive sign convention, this element is absorbing 50 watts of power.

If the current went from low potential to high potential, this would be an active element supplying 50 watts of power.

An interesting thing to note is that the power received is equal to the negative of the power supplied. In other words, this same element absorbing 50 watts of power is also supplying -50 watts of power.

Example

In the same element (V = 5, I = 10), what is the energy across that element over a 10 second interval?

And again, since this element adheres to passive sign convention, this element absorbs (or receives) 500 Joules of power.

Example

Find the power in an element where the current goes from high potential to low potential where V = -4 V and I = 10 A.

The power is equal to -40 watts. Since this adheres to passive sign convention, it absorbs -40 watts; in reality, it may be more natural to say that this element supplies 40 watts.

Chapter 2

Key equations for chapter 2

Ohm's law:
That's really it, but you should also know the difference between dependent and independent sources, as well as what a voltmeter and ammeter is in a physical sense. These become important (or at least useful) later on.

Linear systems
...

what?

This information isn't important for solving problems until chapter 5, when you start working with superposition. But formally speaking, it is important (and probably feels obvious) for solving any circuit where you have multiple things in the circuit.

Everything in this course works with linear systems. It is also possible to determine the properties of a nonlinear system at a given point in time, but it is more complex and will not be covered.

There are two key properties to linear elements - superposition and homogeneity.

Superposition is the principle that the individual stimuli of a system and the individual responses of the same system can be summed up in such a way that the sum of all the stimuli is equal to the sum of all the responses. In simpler terms, if input causes the output and causes , then . The summation of the inputs should not cause the summation of the outputs to change.

Homogeneity is the principle that multiplying the input by some constant must multiply the output by the same constant. In other words,

For example, for the element represented by , you can prove it is linear by applying each principle and observing that the rules adhere. (see slide 6 for chapter 2)

However, for the element represented by , summing two different values of V leads to the square of the sum of the two outputs, rather than the sum of two individual squared outputs. It is nonlinear, since it does not adhere to superposition.

Resistors
...

The ability of a material to resist the flow of charge is known as its resistivity, (greek letter rho). Electrical conductors have low resistivity, while electrical insulators have high resistivity.

The common resistance constant is defined by the following equation:

For example, the resistance in ohms of a cylinder is equal to its resistivity times its length all divided by , where is the radius of the cylinder.

Conductance
...

The conductance of a material is the reciprocal of its resistance:

Conductance is denoted by , and its unit is S, or Siemens. It may also by , or mho. A large G makes it a good conductor, and a small G makes it a poor conductor (as is expected).

The purpose of conductance is to simplify parallel resistor analyses, while conventional resistance is usedd in series resistor analyses.

Independent source
...

An independent source is a source whose supplied value does not depend on other circuit variables. This can be a voltage or current source; its actual value can also be constant or time varying. The key point is that no matter what circuit you put an independent source in, it supplies the same voltage or current.

For example, if an independent source of current supplies 10 A, it will always supply 10 A regardless of the potential difference/voltage across it.

We denote this using the circular battery symbol (+ on one side, - on the other) for independent voltage sources, and an arrow denoting the direction of current inside a circle for independent current sources. (In other words: circle with + and - for independent voltage source, circle with arrow for independent current source.)

Of course, in reality, the voltage of a real source depends on a variety of factors. But we assume here that all sources are ideal, and so they supply voltage or current independent of the current or voltage through the source (respectively).

Open and short circuits
...

An open circuit is a circuit where the current from a current source must pass through air, like a switch being disconnected and thus not closing the circuit. In this case, its resistance is functionally , and its conductance is 0. , and its voltage across the current source is determined by the rest of the circuit.

A short circuit is a circuit where there exists (a path of) no resistance; in other words, its resistance is functionally 0, and its conductance is . The voltage source in this circuit is expressed by , and so the current through the voltage source is determined by the rest of the circuit.

Note that (in this class) these "circuits" are expressed in terms of larger circuits, not that the entire circuit is open or shorted. For example, a parallel circuit in which a junction is not connected to the main loop is locally an open circuit. But there's still a potential difference, so there's still a voltage across the two points of an open circuit. (Think of two water tanks at different levels; cut the connection between them, then the water at the higher level will still have greater potential.)

Likewise, a parallel circuit in which one branch has no resistance has a short circuit, which may cause that line to heat up. There is no voltage (ideally, assuming wire resistance is negligible) across that branch, but there is current still flowing through it.

Slide 23, chapter 2

What's the current through an independent voltage source of 1 V in a circuit of a 100 ohm resistor?

Apply Ohm's law; the current is 0.01 amps.

Voltmeters and ammeters
...

An ideal voltmeter measures the voltage across its terminals and acts like an open circuit; the current going through the voltmeter is almost 0, and its resistance is functionally . When connected to two terminals of a closed circuit, the voltmeter acts like a junction that does not affect the circuit, since its resistance is so high.

An ideal ammeter measures the current flowing through its terminals and acts like a short circuit; the voltage across the ammeter is almost 0, and its resistance is functionally 0. When connected to the two terminals/ends of an open circuit, the ammeter acts like a wire of negligible resistance that does not affect the circuit.

This works because open circuits still have a potential difference across them, and short circuits still have current passing through them.

The meters are connected to a circuit using terminals called probes. They're color-coded to indicate the reference direction of the variable beig measured. Usually, they are red for the positive terminal, and black for the negative terminal.

An ideal voltmeter measures the voltage from the red to the black terminal (i.e. the potential difference from high potential in the circuit to low potential). If you swap the red and black terminals at the same position, you end up with the negative of whatever value you were originally reading. The same applies to ammeters.

If the reading is positive for either an ammeter or a voltmeter, then the electricity flow goes in the direction of positive to negative (i.e. higher potential or electron flow at the positive terminal, less potential or electron flow at the negative terminal.) If it is negative, then the electricity flow actually goes from negative to positive.

Dependent sources
...

Dependent sources model a situation in which the voltage or current of one circuit element is proportional to the voltage or current of the second circuit element.

For example, the output voltage of an amplifier is proportional to the input of that amplifier; the ampliifer's output voltage isn't going to be the same if you put it in a different circuit.

Each dependent source consists of two parts: the controlling part and the controlled part. The controlling part is either an open circuit or short circuit, and the controlled part is either a voltage source or a current source.

Dependent sources (in this class) will be represented by diamond symbols.

A voltage-controlled current source (VCCS) has its gain represented by , which has units of amperes per volt. Therefore, given an input voltage of on an open circuit where the VCCS is inserted, its output current is equal to (and the voltage across it is now .)

Similarly, a current-controlled current source (CCCS) has its gain represented by , which has units of amperes per ampere. Given an input of on a closed circuit where the CCCS is inserted, its output current is equal to (and the voltage across it is ).

Likewise, there are also current-controlled voltage sources (CCVS), and voltage-controleld voltage sources (VCVS). These operate on similar principles. Observe that these are functionally inserted on closed circuits if it is controlled by current, and open circuits if it is controlled by voltage. (Recall voltmeters and ammeters.)

On diagrams, there are three parts to a dependent source - the symbol, its orientation, and the expression used to determine its output relative ot its input. For example, a diamond containing an arrow pointing upwards whose expression is is a voltage-controlled current source, where the gain factor is . In other words, this supplies some current equal to 0.2 times whatever the potential difference across it is (upwards).

why is my source not a source?

Remember - meters never lie, but "sources" can. Just because it's a source (diamond or circle) doesn't mean you should instantly assume that the direction indicated on the source is the flow of current in the circuit. If you're given values, those values are always correct.

Slide 43, chapter 2


The current source supplies 40 watts. What values do the meters read?

First, note that the question states that the current source supplies 40 watts - that is to say, it's an actual source. Therefore, we should expect the voltmeter to read positive, since its positive terminal is located at high potential (directly outside the source) and its negative terminal is located at low potential (right before the source).

Since the power formula is , then substituting values shows , so the voltmeter reads a potential difference of 20 volts.

Now, recall that a voltmeter is an open circuit. Therefore, this circuit is really just a series circuit. We know that the current source is "true", which is to say the current runs in a counterclockwise loop. The ammeter is oriented opposite the current flow (it hits the negative terminal and then the positive terminal), so it will read negative.

Because this is a series circuit, current is constant, and given that the only current-affecting element in the circuit is the current source, the ammeter must read -2 amps.

Slide 28, chapter 2


Find the power supplied by the VCCS.

The voltmeter indicates a positive reading, suggesting that there is higher potential at the positive terminal than at the negative terminal. This also suggests that the VCCS actually adheres to passive sign convention; if it were a "real" source, the arrow should point upwards such that the potential is higher at the start than at the end. Therefore, we know that the "actual" potential difference across it is negative (for now).

The current supplied is equal to the voltage at another point on the circuit multiplied by 4. This works out to , and so the current it supplies is actually -8 amperes.

Curiously, this indicates that it does not adhere to passive sign convention, and is indeed an actual source! The arrow actually points up, and supplies 8 amperes in this case. And since the voltmeter now suggests that it is an active element, and therefore the potential difference is positive. Solving for power:

Therefore, it supplies 17.6 watts of power.

An aside: what if we didn't want to change our conventions as we were moving along? One option is to simply let all the numerical signs remain the same. Therefore, the current it spits out is -8 amps, and the potential difference across it is indeed 2.2 volts. But since the VCCS adheres to passive sign convention (based on the voltmeter directly attached to it, and assuming that the voltage on the other voltmeter also passes from top to bottom), we assume that it is a passive element. Therefore, it receives power.

After calculating for power, we discover that it receives -17.6 watts of power. This is the same thing as saying it supplies 17.6 watts of power.

Most examples in-class do not "correct" the direction of current. The negative voltmeter on the left has its reading taken as-is, and all future calculations are done based on that negative value with the voltage running from left to right across the 0.2 amp resistor.

Revisiting slide 43, chapter 2


What values do the meters read?

We know (for a fact, since the problem gave it to us) that the current source is a true source, supplying 40 watts. Therefore, the voltmeter should read positive, since its positive terminal is oriented at high potential and its negative terminal at low potential.

In contrast, the ammeter should read negative, since its terminals are oriented opposite the direction of current.

Since it supplies 40 watts and it is known to also supply 2 amps, the voltmeter on the right must be 20 volts.

Since this is a series circuit where the sole current is being provided by by the independent current source, the ammeter should read -2 amps (since the ammeter is oriented opposite the flow of current).

Chapter 3
...

Key equations for chapter 3

KVL states that the sum of all voltages in any closed loop is equal to 0.
KCL states that the sum of all currents entering a node is equal to the sum of all voltages exiting a node.
Resistors in series have an equivalent resistance equal to their simple sum:
Resistors in parallel have an equivalent resistance equal to the sum of their reciprocals, all over 1:
or, more typically,
Voltage divider, or the voltage across a single resistor in a series circuit:
Generalized current divider, or the current across a single resistor in a parallel circuit (see Current divider formula for a typical current divider expression):

Terminology
...

Some terms to note in circuits, particularly with respect to Kirchhoff's laws:

  • Branch: A single element in a circuit.
  • Node: The point of connection between two or more branches. In more general terms, a single piece of uninterrupted wire (possibly with junctions) that connects elements together.
  • Loop: Any closed path in a circuit.

Note that a node is not a junction. A corner of a circuit connecting two branches (or two circuit elements) is actually part of a node, but it is not a junction. A junction is a fork; a node simply connects two or more elements. It may be better to think of a "node" as a connected set of wires that connects a set of elements. When the wire is broken up or terminated by elements on all its ends, the node ends.

Kirchhoff's laws
...

There are two key laws:

  • Kirchhoff's current law, or KCL
  • Kirchhoff's voltage law, or KVL

Current law
...

In the current law, it essentially states that charge is conserved. The sum of all currents flowing into a node must equal the sum of all currents flowing out of that node. This is usually represented by
or
Note that this holds true even if the node is a single wire connecting two elements together - the current coming out of the first element should be equal to that going into the second element.

node or junction?

Each color in the image below represents a distinct node, while each dot represents a distinct junction.

It does hold true that the current going into a junction is also equal to the current going out of a junction, so KCL applies for junctions as well. But for the sake of this course, it's much more useful to think of the current law in terms of nodes than in terms of junctions.

Also worth noting is that the definition of a junction isn't agreed upon everywhere. You can often define junction as a fork or "any point where the current splits", but the exact, full definition can vary between physics and engineering.

Voltage law
...

In the voltage law, it essentially states that the sum of voltages around a loop is equal to zero. This is mathematically represented as
which is to say, at any given time , the sum of all voltages is equal to zero.

Ohm's law applies here. Therefore, the current across a resistor of known resistance can be used to find the potential difference across that element. Likewise, voltage sources have their potential difference readily known.

Convention for voltage law and voltmeters
...

TL;DR

The vast majority of examples in this document use PHYS 181 convention. This means that when current runs from high to low potential, it's got a negative sign in front of the resulting voltage. When current runs from low to high potential, it's got a positive sign. This is different from the in-class examples, which do the opposite.

All examples from here on out use PHYS 181 convention, including in future chapters. Be very careful to follow chapter-specific conventions if necessary; the sign convention discussed here primarily affects KCL-like and KVL-like problems.

It is up to you to use a specific convention for the signs of voltage increases and voltage decreases. In PHYS 181, the convention was to treat batteries where current ran from low to high potential as positive. This class suggests treating current entering a negative terminal (i.e. low to high) as negative.

To make it consistent with the idea of meters, it may be better to use the class's convention. Remember that a voltmeter measures the potential difference between the positive terminal and the negative terminal (i.e., voltage = potential at positive - potential at negative). Therefore, connecting the positive terminal to the negative end of the battery and the negative terminal to the positive end of the battery causes there to be a higher potential on the negative terminal, which leads to a negative voltage reading. Therefore, following the loop in the current using EE 220 convention would result in negative voltage.

However, PHYS 181 convention suggests positive voltage (due to a gain in potential). Just make sure your sign convention is consistent - any final answers will always be correct. This is because, algebraically, you can just move everything over to the other side of the expression, which is always 0 (where this convention issue applies). Then, the signs of all the terms will flip.

Also, resistor polarities may not be given. However, because it is a passive element, (using PHYS 181 conventions), you should always define the polarity as high to low potential ahead of time. In other words, once you've decided the directions for all of your currents, make it so that the resistors adhere to passive sign convention.

Note that the direction of a current source is always given, and therefore its polarity can be determined. The arrowhead end is positive; the tail of the arrow is negative.

Series circuits
...

Elements in series have the same current. It also follows that if all the elements in a given circuit (or node) have the same current, then they are connected in series. As a result, the voltage across elements in series varies - that is to say, it is possible for each element in a series circuit to have different potential differences across them.

More precisely, two elements are only connected in series if they are the only two elements on the node.

The voltage at a single resistor is equal to its share of the total resistance times the voltage across the whole series circuit - that is,
This is known as the voltage divider formula. Alternatively, apply Ohm's law.

The equivalent resistance of resistors connected in series is simply the sum of those resistors. In other words,

You can verify these statements using Kirchhoff's laws in a circuit with resistors and a voltage source. (See chapter 3, slide 20.)

In summary, elements connected in series:

  • all have the same current
  • can have varying voltages/potential differences
  • have an equivalent resistance equal to the sum of all the individual resistors

Parallel circuits
...

Elements in parallel are connected such that the voltage across each element is the same. This can be proven by applying Kirchoff's voltage law in each loop in succession.

More precisely, elements are connected in parallel if they share the same two nodes on both sides (the same uninterrupted wire).

It also holds that the currents can vary, such that the equivalent current of the entire circuit is equal to the individual sum of the currents through each (equivalent series) resistor. You can use this to derive the expression for equivalent resistance in a parallel circuit, which is
or, more typically,

parallel or not?

It's important to note that two elements are always in parallel if they share two nodes, regardless if there are other elements in between them.

For example, you'll soon discover that you can combine independent current sources in parallel. You can do this even if there's other elements in between them; in the image below, you'll notice that although these two sources are separated by a resistor, you can combine them regardless and rearrange the circuit accordingly. So long as they share two nodes, they're in parallel.

Slide 47, chapter 3


Determine the resistance measured by the ohmmeter.

The 60 and 30 ohm resistors are in parallel, as they share the same two nodes. Their equivalence is 20 ohms.

It can now be shown that the two 20 ohm resistors are in series (they are connected by one node, where they are the only elements on that node). This yields an equivalent resistance of 40 ohms.

Finally, the 40 and 10 are in parallel. This yields an equivalent resistance of 8 ohms across the meter.

Note that the presence of an ohmmeter cannot be simplified to a short circuit, nor can it ignored. It is true that after the left side is simplified, we are left with a 40 and 10 ohm resistor. In a "normal" problem excluding the ohmmeter, we could indeed treat these as series. However, because of the presence of the ohmmeter which acts like another resistor (a concept explained in class), we must treat the 40 and 10 ohm resistors as parallel, since they are no longer the only resistors on those two nodes.

Multiple voltage and current sources
...

There are only certain combinations of multiple sources connection to each other that are possible.

(Slide 41, chapter 3.)

You are allowed to connected voltage sources in series. If they have identical polarities (i.e. we expect them to flow in the same direction), then the equivalent voltage source is simply the sum of the two voltages they provide individually. If they have opposing polarities, then the equivalent voltage source is the difference between the two voltages they provide.

Connecting voltage sources in parallel is not allowed.

You can connect current sources in parallel. If they have identical directions, the equivalent current source is the simple sum of the individual currents they provide (i.e. ). If they have opposing directions, then it is the simple difference of their individual currents.

Connecting current sources in series is not allowed.

Chapter 4
...

Key points for chapter 4

This chapter doesn't introduce new equations, but rather a bunch of new concepts. It's better to review examples than to try and summarize it here, but here's some quick points:

  • Nodal analysis involves using KCL for each node.
    • When a voltage source has a terminal to ground, then you immediately know that node's voltage - but pay attention to its polarity!
    • When a voltage source is between two nodes, that makes a supernode. Write one equation relating the two nodes to the voltage source, and another huge KCL expression combining both nodes.
  • Mesh analysis involves using KVL for each mesh (or loop).
    • When a current source isn't shared between two meshes, then you immediately know that mesh's voltage - but pay attention to its polarity!
    • When a current source is shared between two meshes, that makes a supermesh. Write one equation relating the two mesh currents that are involved, letting the mesh current in the same direction as the source be positive, and write another huge KVL expression combining both meshes.

We will introduce two new variables - node voltages and mesh currents.

  • The node voltage method (nodal/node analysis) uses node voltage equations, where the uknown variables are the node voltages.
  • The mesh current method (mesh analysis) uses mesh current equations, where the unknown variables are the mesh currents.

These equations are expressed in systems of linear equations. Solve them as desired. Substitution, matrices, etc. are all permitted - that is to say, algebra, Cramer's rule, or linear algebra may all be used. Because any calculator is allowed, you may use whatever you want. (In the slides, Cramer's rule is required, but is not explicitly mentioned in class.)

These analysis techniques are powerful, moreso than the intuitive analysis techniques of equivalent resistances, KCL/KVL, and so on.

Nodal analysis
...

First, identify your nodes. Select one node to be the reference node, or the ground node. By convention, this is usually the node at the bottom. The voltage at ground is considered to be 0 V, and then you determine the voltage of all of the other nodes relative to that ground node. Use the ground symbol to show which node has been selected as the reference node.

Now, the voltage at all of the other nodes is expressed in terms of unknown node voltages. You then apply Kirchhoff's current law to obtain the currents in terms of node voltages.

Note that we usually know the value of a voltage source. For example, if the voltage across an element is 5 volts, then the positive terminal has a higher potential than the negative terminal. One valid difference would be 40 volts at the positive terminal, and 35 volts at the negative terminal. Observe that the two sides of an element are (usually) connected to two distinct nodes, and so we can relate the values of two of the node voltages, (positive terminal) and (negative terminal) respectively.

Likewise, the value of a resistor is also typically known. Again, the potential difference across the resistor is the potential at the positive end minus the potential at the negative end - that is, . Applying Ohm's law shows that we can express the current across a resistor as a function of the node voltages:

Of course, for a resistor which is connected directly to the ground/reference node on its negative end, that might mean . In that case, the current across that resistor is simply .

After determining the expressions for current across each element, we now extend Kirchhoff's current law to say that the current entering a single node (rather than a junction) must equal the current exiting that same node.

For example, for the circuit shown below:

The top-left node has the indepndent current source as the "entering" current, and the positive terminals of the two resistors as the "exiting" current.

Likewise, on the top-right node, the negative terminal of is the entering terminal (by the direction we established in the top-left node), and the positive terminal of is the exiting node. Therefore, the current across minus the current across is equal to 0 (using the current expressions shown earlier for the current across a resistor).

At this point, you now have a system of equations. Solve using the given values as applicable to find the node voltages. With the node voltages, it becomes possible to find the individual values for current and resistance across individual elements, if necessary. Note how this can be very powerful - it allows you to solve for fewer unknowns before analyzing the circuit.

With voltage sources
...

The previous examples worked because there were no additional voltage sources. But what if there are voltage sources?

We have two distinct cases - one terminal of the voltage source is connected to ground, and no terminals of the voltage source are connected to ground.

No terminals to ground (supernode)
...

Since the voltage source is not connected to ground, it is impossible to immediately determine the node voltages (remember: voltage is relative, and it was only possible to determine it before because we knew the ground node was equal to 0 volts).

However, we do know a relationship between the two nodes the voltage source is connected to. The node voltage on the positive side is volts higher than the node voltage on the negative side. To solve for the two node voltages surrounding the voltage source, we can write a system of equations which relates the two node voltages together.

However, the simpler version is to simply combine the nodes to form what is known as a supernode or generalized node, which consists of two nodes connected by an independent or dependent voltage source. Notably, the sum of the currents entering a supernode is also equal to 0.

If you treat the nodes separately, then there are two things you will need:

  • the expression relating the two original nodes, at the positive end and at the negative end, to
  • a full KCL experssion for KCL on the two nodes.

This allows you to create a system of equations that solves for the two relevant nodes on either side of the voltage source.

However, it is often simpler to simply treat the two connected nodes as one node, in which you simply write the expression relating the two original nodes and combine that with a KCL expression for the sum of all currents going into and out of the combined node.

In the picture above, you can simply use the two following expressions, where the first expression relates the two terminals of the voltage source and the second is the combined KCL expression for the supernode:

This allows you to substitute values into one KCL equation, rather than having two KCL equations to solve.

Mesh analysis
...

In mesh analysis, we instead apply KVL around loops in the circuit. In nodal analysis, we got a system of linear equations where we had unknown node voltages. In mesh analysis, we end up with a system of linear equations that must be solved for unknown mesh currents.

Meshes are simply loops in the circuit. To begin mesh analysis, we assign a current with direction to each mesh. Then, we apply KVL around each mesh to get an equation in terms of the mesh currents.

In mesh analysis, it's possible for two currents of different directions to pass through a single resistor (if it's in between two different meshes, each with their own mesh current). Therefore, we need to establish the voltage across those resistors.

  • If there is a single current passing through R that adheres to passive sign convention, the voltage is simply equal to the mesh current times the resistance. This is typically expressed as , where is the mesh current of mesh 1.
  • If there are two currents passing through R, then the net current across the resistor is equal to the current adhering to the passive convention minus the current that does not adhere to passive convention. This is expressed as , where is passive and is active.

The image below shows the result of the expressions above. (This image is from slide 7, chapter 4: mesh analysis.)

Now, if you apply KVL using these rules for a two-mesh circuit, you'll end up with two equations each with two variables, which can then be solved through a system of equations.

There are two ways to write the KVL equations:

  • Adhere to "standard" KVL, giving all resistors a polarity to start with. Currents that adhere to passive sign convention on that resistor are always positive; currents that do not adhere to passive sign convention are always negative.
  • When writing the KVL equations for each mesh (more specifically, when writing the current expressions at a resistor), always treat the current for the current mesh as positive. If a resistor shares a mesh current with another mesh, treat that current as negative. In other words, when evaluating mesh 1, where a resistor is between mesh 1 and mesh 2, treat mesh 1 as positive and mesh 2 as negative. Flip the signs when writing the KVL expression with respect to mesh 2.

All examples in class use the second convention, where the mesh current being analyzed is always positive for any given KVL expression.

Choosing a method of analysis
...

So what option should you use?

You may want to to use node analysis if:

  • You need to find unknown voltages
  • You do not have voltage sources
  • You have voltage sources, but any voltage sources are connected to the reference node (which simpilifies the node voltage expressions by yielding immediate answers to node voltages)
  • There are fewer nodes than meshes (which results in you solving fewer equations)

You may want to use mesh analysis if:

  • You need to find unknown currents
  • You do not have current sources
  • If you do have current current sources, they only affect one mesh and don't require supermesh expressions (and yields immediate answers to mesh currents)
  • There are fewer meshes than nodes (again, resulting in fewer equations)

Since there are only two nodes plus the (given) reference node, we choose nodal analysis.

Key equations for chapter 5

The maximum power transfer theorem states that when , or when the load resistance is equal to the Thevinin resistance, maximum power is delivered to the load resistor if it is connected to a Thevenin circuit. The maximum power is

Key methods for chapter 5

Superposition: "Turn off" all the independent sources except one - that is, replace voltage sources with short circuits, and current sources with an open circuit. Solve for your unknown current or voltage across a certain element assuming only that one independent source existed (and any dependent sources that you can't remove), and then do that for all the independent sources. Add them up, and that's your answer.

Thevenin and Norton circuits; source transformation: A Thevenin circuit is a simplified circuit where you have a voltage source in series with a resistor . A Norton circuit is a simplified circuit where you have a current source in parallel with a resistor . You can convert between the two easily with the knowledge that and .

Applying Thevenin's/Norton's theorem: The steps are approximately:

  • To find or , create an open or short circuit across terminals a and b (or the element to be analyzed) and solve for either.
  • To find if there are no dependent sources, remove all the independent sources and simplify the resistors.
  • To find if there are dependent sources, you must find both and and use .

This chapter involves a variety of circuit theorems, many of which are strategies for simplifying circuits. Each theorem says that certain circuits are equivalent to other circuits - for example, the idea that a voltage source and series resistor can be replaced by a current source and parallel resistor.

Superposition
...

Superposition states that the output of a linear circuit due to several inputs working together is equal to the sum of the responses due to each input working separately.

To use superposition, turn of all independent sources except for one. Then, find the output voltage or current of that source in the circuit that remains. Repeat for each independent source, and then add the contribution of each source to find the total output in the whole circuit.

What does it mean to "turn off" a source?

  • Replace voltage sources with a short circuit (such that its output is 0 volts).
  • Replace current sources with an open circuit (such that its output is 0 amps).

(This occurs because you end up with a series circuit by replacing with an open circuit.) Therefore, the voltage across the 2 kresistor as a result of the independent voltage source is equal to .

Likewise, if you take out the independent voltage source, you end up with with just . Replacing with a short circuit leaves two resistors in parallel, and the equivalent resistance is 1000 ohms. Since voltage is constant in parallel, this means that the voltage across the equivalent resistance is equal to the voltage across the 2 kresistor. Therefore, the voltage across that resistor as a result of the independent current source is equal to , following Ohm's law.

The result is that , adding the individual voltages from each source.

Source transformation
...

Most of the time, we deal with mixed current and voltage sources. We would prefer a circuit that mostly contains one type of source.

Source transformation is the principle that sources can be replaced with sources of the other type without changing the circuit as a whole, given that you perform very specific replacements.

Two circuits are equivalent if they have the same voltage-current relationship at their terminals - that is, the ratio of the voltage to the current is identical.

(Slide 17, chapter 5.)

We have two transformations that we can perform:

  • Replace a voltage source in series with a resistor with a current source in parallel with a resistor. Let , and . This means that the current source becomes equal to the voltage output divided by the resistance in series, and the new resistor in parallel becomes equal in value to the resistance in series.
  • Replace a current source in series with a resistor by a voltage source in parallel with a resistor. Let , and . The voltage source becomes equal to the original current output times the resistor in parallel, and the new resistor in series becomes equal in value to the resistance in series.

This is described in the image below (Slide 18, chapter 5.). Observe that the polarity remains the same after the source transformation.

You can prove this by applying KVL and KCL to the respective circuits - see slide 20, chapter 5.

Thevenin and Norton circuits
...

The source transformations that we performed earlier have names. We refer to a voltage source in series with a resistor as a Thevenin circuit, and a current source in parallel with a resistor as a Norton circuit.

As discussed in source transformations, the replacement of these circuits with the other type does not change the voltage or current of any element outside the replacement. So if we have a massive circuit connected to a Thevenin circuit and replace it with a Norton circuit (or vice versa), the massive circuit remains wholly the same.

Thevenin's theorem
...

To apply Thevenin's theorem to solve for the voltage across a specific part of a circuit, or to simplify it into a Thevenin circuit:

  • Replace the element in question with an open circuit and find the voltage across it, usually denoted . ("Element" here can be an actual element like a load resistor, or simply the part of the circuit past terminals a and b.)
  • Find the internal resistance of the remainder of the circuit, . (Remember - you're trying to find the equivalent resistance for the Thevenin circuit, not the element or the entire circuit including the element. It may make more sense to turn the element into an open circuit before performing the resistor simplifications, making it clear that refers to the resistors in the circuit you're simplifying.)
    • If there are no dependent sources, turn off (remove) all independent sources from the circuit and determine the equivalent resistance of the circuit being simplified. (Voltage sources become short circuits; current sources become open circuits.) You should end up with one node/wire in series, from terminal a to b, that you can then find for.
    • If there are dependent sources, then apply the expression . This requires that you solve for the short circuit current in a Norton equivalent circuit by short circuiting the two terminals. (See the next section, Norton's theorem, for examples.)
  • The voltage of the Thevenin circuit is equal to the voltage across the open circuited element; that is, .
  • The resistance of the Thevenin circuit is equal to , calculated earlier.
on the subject of finding

When calculating in a circuit with no dependent sources, make sure you start from the original circuit - when finding the open circuit voltage, you may have removed a resistor. You must include this resistor for , so make sure you start from the original circuit that was given to you.

We can refer to the part of the circuit being analyzed as a black box; it does not matter what that circuit is. The Thevenin circuit it is connected to will still hold, and can be used in additional analyses as necessary. (In simpler terms; anything past the terminals you make an open circuit on will be unaffected.)

Use Thevenin's theorem to find the current through the 2 ohm resistor .

Under Thevenin's theorem, we begin by finding the voltage across the resistor R if it were an open circuit. Since the resistance becomes functionally equivalent to infinity, this means that no current flows through the 4 ohm resistor at the top connected in series.

But there still exists a potential difference across the two terminals of the open circuit. Since no current runs through the 4 ohm resistor, we can simplify this circuit to just the 60 volt source and the 5 and 20 ohm resistors. The equivalent resistance of the 5 and 20 ohm resistor in series with the 4 ohm resistor is equal to 8 ohms. Therefore, .

With this, we now have everything we need to construct the Thevenin circuit.

  • Place a voltage source equal in output to the voltage across the open circuit. This means we place a 48 volt source.
  • Place the equivalent resistance of everything to the side of the blackboxed circuit - that is, the 2 ohm resistor R. This means that we place an 8 ohm resistor in series with the source and the blackboxed circuit.

We now have a 48 volt source in series with a 2 ohm and 8 ohm resistor. Since current in constant in series, we simply apply Ohm's law to find the current , noting that the series equivalent resistance is 10 ohms:

Norton's theorem
...

To apply Norton's theorem to solve for the current across a specific part of a circuit, or to solve it for a Norton circuit:

  • Replace the element in question with a short circuit and find the current across it, usually denoted . ("Element" here can be an actual element like a load resistor, or simply the part of the circuit past terminals a and b.)
  • Find the internal resistance of the reminder of the circuit, . (Remember - you're trying to find the equivalent resistance for the Norton circuit, not the element or the entire circuit including the element. It may make more sense to turn the element into an open circuit before performing the resistor simplifications, making it clear that refers to the resistors in the circuit you're simplifying.)
    • If there are no dependent sources, turn off (remove) all independent sources from the circuit and determine the equivalent resistance of the circuit being simplified. (Voltage sources become short circuits; current sources become open circuits.) You should end up with one node/wire in series, from terminal a to b, that you can then find for.
    • If there are dependent sources, then apply the expression . This requires that you solve for the open circuit voltage in a Thevenin equivalent circuit by open circuiting the two terminals. (See the previous section, Thevenin's theorem, for examples.)
  • The current of the Norton circuit is equal to the current across the short circuited element; that is, .
  • The resistance of the Norton circuit is equal to , calculated earlier.
on the subject of finding

When calculating in a circuit with no dependent sources, make sure you start from the original circuit - when finding the short circuit current, you may have removed a resistor. You must include this resistor for , so make sure you start from the original circuit that was given to you.

As with Thevenin circuits, anything past the terminals is unaffected by converting from a "normal" circuit to a Norton circuit (since the two are equivalent).

Maximum power transfer
...

At a very high level, you can treat the power grid as a Thevenin equivalent circuit in which the voltage source and equivalent resistance is equal to the Thevenin component, and the rest of the circuit is a resistor, your home. (This is usually called a load resistor. Resistors absorb power, so your home can be accurately represented with a resistor.)

So what is the power through the load resistor? The conventional epxression for power is . Observe that the circuit above is simply a series circuit, where by Ohm's law and series resistor equivalence. As a result, the power absorbed by the load is equal to:
(where this is derived from , substituting in in .)

The maximum power transfer theorem states that the maximum power delivered to a load by a source is attained when the load resistance is equal to the Thevenin resistance of the source. In other words, if the power company wants to maximize the power to your house, they need to have an equivalent load on their end, as well.

(You can prove the maximum power transfer theorem graphically or by applying partial derivatives. A calculus-based proof is on slide 47, chapter 5. In short, the maximum of the power transferred vs. load resistance function exists where the derivative is equal to 0, or . This only occurs if in the image above.)

With this knowledge, we can allow in the expression for the power absorbed by the load. This will yield an expression for the maximum power that can be abosrbed by the load (or, more accurately, the power abosrbed by the load when the power transfer is maximized):

Chapter 6

Key concepts for chapter 6

There aren't any new equations, but the main thing to remember here are the conditions for an ideal operational amplifier:

  • The input voltages are equal to each other; that is, .
  • The input currents are both equal to 0; that is, .

These are particularly important, since they'll give you information in nodal analysis that will be necessary for solving the circuit.

This chapter also gives you specific operational amplifier circuits (inverting, noninverting, summing, difference, and buffer amplifiers), but you don't need to memorize them as they'll be on the cover sheet for exams. It's also often more intuitive to just use node analysis, which will always work.

Introduction
...

All images in the introduction section below come from the start of the chapter 6 slides. You may also want to check out the Wikipedia page on operational amplifiers for more details outside of actual EE 220 problems.

This chapter involves circuits with operational amplifiers. Fundamentally, operational amplifiers amplify a voltage input, up to the limits defined by its voltage supplies. The potential difference across its inputs are often very small, but the output voltage can be 100,000 times larger than the input voltage. In terms of water, an operational amplifier is much like a valve - opening the valve results in some output of water corresponding to how much the valve was opened.

Operational amplifiers are widely used in performing mathematical operations, as in a calculator. In practice, a variety of analysis models are available, where the simplest model is the ideal operational amplifier. Accurate models are more complicated, and have properties that are not included in the ideal operational amplifier that require other models to analyze them. Circuits with ideal operational amplifiers are typically analyzed by writing and solving node equations.

The symbol for an operational amplifier is a triangle (pointing left or right) with a non-inverting input into the positive terminal on the flat end, and an inverting input on the negative terminal on the flat end. The output is on the pointed end.

Note that the ideal operational amplifier also includes high supplies, low supplies, and ground; however, the high and low supplies, or rails, are typically omitted from circuit diagrams. That does not mean the operational amplifier has no power, of course. The high and low supplies provide the variable voltage for the operational amplifier to output.

It turns out that we can approximately model an operational amplifier with the following equivalent circuit:

And this makes it a little clearer that it amplifies the difference of the voltages across the input terminals - that is, . If you don't want to amplify that difference at all, then you simply let the gain equal 1. (Note that the gain is equal to the ratio , so it's unitless.)

Are operational amplifiers linear? They are, within the range defined on their rails. It should make logical sense that the output voltage cannot exceed the voltages supplied on their high and low supplies (rails), which is in practice often set to be between -15 and 15 volts. If the would-be output exceeds this range, it simply goes to the relevant extreme value, since it cannot go further.

Ideal operational amplifiers
...

There are some special considerations that we make in an ideal operational amplifier, as opposed to the approximate model pictured above. We assume the following:


  • (where the relevant variables correspond to the "approximate model" circuit in the picture above.)

We do this since this allows us to make assumptions about our inputs. When the gain is very high and the output voltage is some smaller, finite value, this requires the difference between the input voltages to be very, very small. For example, if the gain is 10000 and the output voltage is 20 volts, then needs to be 2 millivolts. Then, minor changes in the input voltages can cause saturation, where the output is outside the ranges of the operational amplifier and cannot be properly done.

This is an extremely small difference, such that and are virtually equal to each other. We call this a virtual short condition, where . This is the first condition in an ideal operational amplifier.

(Why is the virtual short condition helpful? In practice, it implies that the gain needs to be very close to infinity for anything to come out of . Analyzing the approximate model yields some terms that are proportional to , and if , then those terms disappear and simplify the circuit.)

The second condition in an ideal operational amplifier is that the input currents are equal to 0, which allows and to be attained. This is important since chaining operational amplifiers is common, and it is only possible to maintain these conditions across many ideal operational amplifiers if the input currents on both inputs are 0.

This is a little clearer in the images below, where the first image shows two chained operational amplifiers, and the second shows how acts like an independent source in a series circuit with in its own op amp and in the next op amp.

If is infinity, then applying the voltage divider formula shows that practically all of the voltage drop occurs across . With equal to 0, then the voltage drop across the output is practically 0. This means that you know the exact voltage input (rather than some slightly lower value due to ), and you also know the exact voltage output since there isn't any power/voltage lost to .

The use of the ideal model greatly simplifies analysis, compared to approximate and accurate models. In sum, the fundamental assumptions made are:

  • (The two input voltages are the same.)
  • (There is no input current.)

Design using operational amplifers
...

A major early application of operational amplifiers was to build circuits that could perform math operations. Such circuits became common enough to be given a name. The ones covered in this class are:

  • inverting amplifier
  • noninverting amplifier
  • summing amplifier
  • difference amplifier
  • buffer amplifier (voltage follower)
do i need to memorize these?

You don't really need to be able to identify and name any circuit with an operational amplifier. All circuits can be analyzed using nodal analysis with the approach described earlier. However, being able to identify what kind of circuit a certain operational amplifier is will allow you to just jump directly to the equations below, saving some time analyzing the circuit relationships.

Pictures of these circuits and their associated expressions will be provided on exam cover sheets.

Cascade amplifiers
...

A cascade amplifier is a setup where you have multiple operational amplifiers in series. This can be useful in mathematical operations, whereby you chain operations together using the circuits mentioned earlier. We also call such setups "2-stage amplifiers," where the first stage consists of the input and output of the first operational amplifier and the second stage is everything past that.

Many of the techniques for analyzing these circuits stays the same, although there are a few additional steps.

Chapter 7
...

where's the summary?

A summary for both would take up a full two pages, so the individual expressions for capacitors and inductors are in their own respective sections.

Introduction
...

Chapter 7 addresses two circuit elements - the capacitor (with capacitance, ) and the inductor (with inductance, ). These are special in that they are capable of storing energy. But more importantly, because they can store energy, this means that they may either produce or absorb energy at varying times.

So far, we have assumed that everything in a circuit happens instantaneously; but now, we must analyze these circuits over some nonzero period of time. We call circuits containing capacitors and/or inductors "dynamic circuits."

The equations for these elements involve either integration or differentation. The expressions for capacitor voltages and inductor currents are continuous functions of time.

Returning to the usual water examples, you can think of these energy-storing systems as a water pipe connected to a cup, which stores water. It takes some nonzero amount of time for the water to fill the cup. It also takes some nonzero amount of time for the water to leave the cup.

Capacitors store energy in an electric field. Inductors store energy in a magnetic field. Both of them are passive elements; they can store energy supplied by a circuit and can return that stored energy to a circuit, but they may not supply more energy to a circuit than what a source supplies to it.

Capacitors are typically used to model computers and other electronics, like power supplies. Inductors are used to model motors.

why use one over the other? (or, how they behave differently)

You'll notice that capacitors and inductors both store energy, so why aren't they interchangable? The reason is that their behavior while storing energy is different.

While a capacitor charges, current continues flowing through the circuit; once it's finished charging, current stops flowing through the circuit, since the potential difference across it is equal to the voltage source. Current starts flowing again when its input voltage varies; in other words, capacitors resist changes to voltage.

In contrast, an inductor always tries to oppose changes in current. While an inductor is charging from no stored energy, it will resist increase in current; but when an inductor loses its input current when charged, it will resist the decrease in current. Thus, inductors resist changes to current.

Another way to think about it is that capacitors are like springs; you can squeeze it to put potential energy in it, and then when you let go, it'll also spit that potential energy back out. Inductors are like large water wheels with inertia; it's not instantly going to move with the water when it starts passing through it, but it's also not instantly going to stop if the water stops flowing through it.

There are, of course, more nuances, but this is a simple overview as to how their behaviors differ that might be helpful if you're wondering why circuits act a certain way over time when you have capacitors and inductors in them.

or
Capacitors in parallel combine like series resistors; that is,

Capacitors have a parameter unsurprisingly called capacitance, which represents the ability of a device to store energy in the form of a separated charge or an electric field. Capacitance occurs when two conductors, usually plates, are separated by a dielectric, or an insulator.

Over time, as electrons travel to the capacitor, the capacitor stores a potential difference equal to its input voltage. Then, that voltage can then be released over time. So if you put a 9V source in series with a capacitor, the capacitor will eventually accumulate enough electrons/charge to give it a potential difference of 9 volts.

It's important to note that electrons continue to flow throughout the circuit until the capacitor is fully charged. This means that there is only a current through the capacitor while there is a change in voltage through the capacitor. We may express this as
so that when , this implies that is a constant.

(There's a great visualization of this behavior on YouTube, beginning at about 1:40 on a video called Capacitors and Capacitance: Capacitor physics and circuit operation.)

or

An inductor is simply a coil of wire around a magnetic core. Then, if you want to store energy, you run current through the wire.

We express inductance in the unit Henrys, or H, and the expression for inductance is
where is the inductance, is the number of turns, is the magnetic permeability of the core, is the cross-sectional area of the inductor, and is the length of the inductor. You can see that shorter inductors with more turns have higher inductance.

An inductor wants to keep the current flowing through it the same. For example, let's say that there's normally 10 amps of current flowing through it. It has a voltage of 0 volts across it, since it makes no effort to oppose the current.

But if the current increases, it will generate a negative voltage (in the direction of current flow) so that an opposing current is effectively generated across the inductor, thus balancing the current and keeping it at 10 amps. The same occurs in the opposite direction. Eventually, the current through the capacitor will eventually match that of the new current.

An analogy to Lenz's law

You might remember Lenz's law from PHYS 181L, where dropping a magnet throuch a conducting loop (like a wire) causes some current to be generated that opposes the change in magnetic flux.

Inductors are very similar; they oppose changes in current when there's a change to the initial current, and don't do anything while the current is constant. LIkewise, Lenz's law states that an opposing magnetic flux is generated when a magnet is dropped through the loop, and no such magnetic flux is generated when the magnet stays in one position.

In practice, inductors are useful in that they can maintain a target current for a period of time, even if there is little to no input current. Thus, it can have a greater output voltage than its input voltage.

Key concepts for chapter 8

When analyzing the complete response for these circuits, at a very high level, you'll need to do the following:

  • Isolate the capacitor or inductor, combining capacitors or inductors so that you have exactly one capacitor or one inductor.

  • Draw the circuit prior to the switch closing or opening; that is, the steady state circuit prior to the time next to the time-triggered switch. Replace inductors with short circuits and capacitors with open circuits, then solve for the initial current across the inductor or the initial voltage across the capacitor. (More accurately, solve for or where the inductor or capacitor was.)

  • Draw the circuit after the switch closing or opening; that is, the transient phase circuit after (or at) the time next to the time-triggered switch. Then, for capacitors, solve for the Thevenin equivalent circuit (as described in Chapter 5). For inductors, solve for the Norton equivalent circuit.

  • Apply the complete response expressions above, substituting in the Norton short circuit current for or the Thevenin open circuit voltage for , and the Thevenin/Norton equivalent resistance for .

    You may have additional steps after this, depending on what the question's asked you for; just remember that all of the past analysis approaches (node analysis, mesh, etc.) still apply.

You must draw two separate circuits for the steady state and transient phases!

weird things about chapter 8

Although all of the approaches in this chapter are relatively straightforward individually, you might find yourself solving for unfamiliar Thevenin and Norton circuits. Similarly, you might have switches do things to a circuit that seem to make no sense.

Although these weren't covered in the class slides, they are in the homework. If you want more, see Extra: special circuits in Chapter 8.

Introduction
...

Circuits containing only one inductor and no capacitors or only one capacitor and no inductors can be represented by a first-order differential equation. We call these first-order circuits. In this class, we'll only deal with first-order circuits; that is, one storage element in a circuit plus some amount of sources and resistors.

To analyze circuits with a capacitor or inductor, we'll use Thevenin and Norton equivalent circuits. The goal here is to isolate either the capacitor or inductor from the rest of the circuit. Since capacitors resist changes to voltage, this means that you'll be solving for a Thevenin equivalent circuit; since inductors resist changes to current, your goal is to solve for a Norton equivalent circuit.

First-order RC (resistor-capacitor) circuit
...

Once you've reduced a circuit down to just a voltage source and resistor (a Thevenin circuit) and a capacitor, applying KVL yields , where is the voltage across the capacitor as a function of time.

You can take some derivatives to yield the differential equation
where is the capacitance of the capacitor and is (typically) the voltage supplied by the voltage source. It turns out that the complete response of this differential equation is

equations

A proof of this is provided in the textbook. You'll only need to know the complete response, not the differential equation.

Now, if you remember the generic voltage versus time graph for a capacitor, you'll see that it charges, plateaus (in a given constant-voltage circuit), and then discharges. The time where its voltage changes is known as its transient phase, and the response itself is called the transient response. The time where its voltage remains constant is known as its steady state response, which occurs at any plateau - including if the discharged capacitor remains at .

Combining the transient (such that is small) and steady state response (such that ) yields the complete response, the expression of which we found above.

Worth noting is that is the final value of the capacitor's voltage; is the initial voltage. Then refers to the steady state response, which is the first term; refers to the transient response, which is the second term. We call the time constant .

terminology

The steady state response, or forced response, is the part of the voltage function that remains after enough time has passed. The transient response, or natural response, is the part of the voltage function that disappears after enough time has passed.

Furthermore, analyzing the complete response expression shows that voltage as a function of time is an exponential curve. Of interest is that when we let , evaluating the expression shows us that if on the rising edge, the capacitor has charged to ~63% of its final value. Likewise, if on the falling edge, the capacitor has discharged to ~37% of its final value (or maximum capacity).

You can prove this and discover that is what you get for the rising edge, allowing and . Likewise, you you do this for the falling edge, allowing and .

When , the expression ends up being .

You will notice that only the exponent for changes, and indeed, the graphs for these two capacitors have identical shapes:

But you'll notice that the 1 mF capacitor hits 5 volts 1000 times faster than the 1 F capacitor.

The point of this example is to show that a smaller time constant means that the capacitor charges more quickly in the same circuit, since the capacitor is still charged at a comparable rate with less capacity.

so why not just use really small capacitors all the time?

You might remember from chapter 7 that the voltage difference through the two conducting plates of a capacitor is proportional to the charge; that is,
so even though the voltage across both capacitors here are the same, the second capacitor holds much less charge. As a result, if the voltage in the circuit were to change, the 1 mF capacitor would quickly lose its charge.

A more practical example is in cameras with a dedicated flash; those often have capacitors that charge up and let off all of their charge at once, when the flash needs to be activated. A small capcitor probably wouldn't make for a very bright light.

First-order RL (resistor-inductor) circuit
...

If we do a similar process for our Norton circuit connected to an inductor, we'll get a complete response of
which has a very similar form to the complete response of an RC circuit. The transient and steady state concepts from RC circuits also hold for RL circuits.

Initial conditions
...

There are a few initial conditions for analyzing these two circuits:

  • The independent voltage and current sources are constant DC sources, and do not change with time.
  • The circuit must include exactly one capacitor or exactly one inductor; if there are multiple capacitors or resistors, you need to find its equivalent.
  • The charge in capacitor voltage or inductor current is not instantaneous, but continuous.

We denote the time immediately before the switch opens/closes as , and the time immediately after the switch opens/closes as . The capacitor voltage or inductor current have the same values right before and right after the switch closes.

What switch? You need some trigger to tell the capacitor when to start charging. We usually do this using time-triggered switches, denoted by an arrowhead on a switch with some time next to it. If the arrow points away from the wire for , then the switch is opens at (and is closed for and is open for ). Likewise, if the arrow points towards the wire, then the switch is open for and is closed for .

In the real world, when you flip a switch in a room to turn on a light, the circuit very briefly goes into a transient phase where a capacitor charges or discharges, after which the light stays on at a constant brightness in a steady state phase. (Of course, there are some nuances, but this is a pretty close analogy.) It may seem instant, but the transient phase has some nonzero duration.

Worth noting is that because you're flipping switches, connections between different parts of the circuit are inherently being made or broken. This means you must draw the circuit prior to the switch and after the switch, noting that some elements (like resistors) may "disappear", just like with Thevenin and Norton circuit solving. Furthermore:

  • A capacitor in a DC circuit behaves like an open circuit in steady state.
  • An inductor in a DC circuit behaves like a short circuit in steady state.
    This is consistent with the principles in the previous chapter (the inductor "disappears" when it's fully charged and "appears" when the current in the circuit changes; the capacitor "disappears" while charging and "appears" when fully charged, blocking current flow.)
