Extra: special circuits in Chapter 8
...

There are two new things you'll probably run into while trying to make Thevenin and Norton circuits in this chapter:

  • Solving for a Thevenin or Norton circuit where the element is in the middle rather than on the (right) edge of the circuit
  • Switches that cause entire parts of circuits to disappear or get isolated, including the capacitor or inductor itself.

Here's an example for each.

A capacitor in the middle


Solve for the voltage across the capacitor as a function of time after the switch closes at .

If the inductor or capacitor is in the middle of the circuit, then you will need to figure out what the short circuit current or open circuit voltage across it is in-place; that is, don't try to move the inductor or capacitor anywhere. You can apply nodal/mesh if necessary, or simply try to find the component where the open circuit voltage applies to (for capacitors).

For this question, we begin by replacing the capacitor with an open circuit and finding the open circuit voltage (where there once was a capacitor). Since the switch is open for , this means the right half of the circuit effectively disappears. Furthermore, we're trying to find the voltage across an open circuit in a series circuit; is simply equal to 18 volts. You can prove this by pretending the open circuit is an infinite-resistance resistor and applying voltage divider, or applying nodal analysis.

Then, the steady state voltage (prior to the switch closing) is equal to 18 volts. We've finished evaluating our first half of the problem.

Now, we'll close the switch, giving us our transient phase circuit. Now, we need to find the Thevenin equivalent circuit. We begin by finding , which happens to be equal to the voltage across the 40 ohm resistor. Applying voltage divider shows that the final voltage is equal to 14.4 volts.

As for the equivalent resistance, you can pretend open circuits are actually infinite-resistance resistors, if it makes more sense to think about the relationships between the other resistors. So if there are two resistors on either side of the open circuit in a loop, you actually have two resistors in parallel - not two resistors in series.

After removing the 18 volt independent source and pretending we have an infinite resistance resistor in the center connecting the two parts of the circuit, we find that the 40 and 10 ohm resistors are connected in parallel. So the equivalent resistance for the image above is 8 ohms, not 50 ohms.

but wouldn't this just be a series circuit?

You might be looking at the image above and wondering why the resistors aren't just connected in series, so the equivalent resistance is 40+10=50 ohms. After all, an open circuit is the same thing as no wire being there.

But remember that when finding a Thevnein circuit, it's not like the element in question on the other side just disappears. So you can't just "remove" the open circuit, because now the you found earlier isn't really measuring across anything. Everything to one side of the Thevenin circuit is black-boxed; in other words, you must isolate for that capacitor, which is currently an open circuit, and those terminals must stay present.

If it feels more natural, you can treat the open circuit as an infinite-resistance resistor. Then, you can apply your regular parallel resistor theorems, move the infinite-resistance resistor to the far-right, and combine the 10 ohm and 40 ohm resistor in parallel.

So your final values are , , and . You can substitute those into the complete response expression for capacitors accordingly.

Generally, you should try and figure out a way to isolate the capacitor or inductor if possible, as it'll make your Thevenin/Norton circuit more straightforward to solve.

A switch making half the circuit disappear


Solve for the current through the inductor as a function of time after the switch opens at .

First, we need to evaluate our steady state circuit, which is where the switch is closed. Replace the inductor with a short circuit, and find the current at that point.

You can do this a variety of ways (like a bunch of chained mesh analyses), but I'll do source transformations and resistor/source combinations. Although I'll jump over drawing the individual simplifications you need to do, here's an overview:

  • The 20 V source and 4 ohm resistor in series to the left turn into a 5 A source and 4 ohm resistor in parallel. (source transformation)
  • The 4 ohm, 12 ohm, and 3 ohm resistors are all in parallel - you can confirm this by observing they all share the same two nodes. Their equivalent resistance is 1.5 ohms.
  • The 9 A and 5 A source both point upwards and are in parallel, so you can combine them. Their equivalent is a single 14 A source.

This leaves you with a 14 amp source in parallel with a 1.5 ohm resistor. Applying source transformation leaves you with a series circuit with a 21 volt source, a 10.5 ohm resistor, and the original short circuit you started with. Since current is constant in series, the current is simply 2 A. This finishes off our steady state evaluation.

We move onto the transient phase by opening the switch. Now, you might notice this causes an interesting thing to happen - there exists no way for current that goes in through the top to go back out. The net result? There's no current flowing through the entire right half of the circuit after the switch opens. So the final current is equal to 0 amps, since .

But we still have to find the equivalent resistance. But what resistors do we combine? Again, remember that we've effectively isolated our left and right halves of the circuit by opening that switch. It's true that there's no current that will go out through the top half; so when we find the equivalent resistance, we can completely ignore all of the resistors and stuff to the left half of the circuit. We still have a closed loop through which current can flow on the right half of the circuit.

In essence, this leaves us with a series circuit with a 9 and 3 ohm resistor. As a result, the equivalent resistance of our Norton circuit is 12 ohms, even though there's no current flowing through the right half.

The final values you substitute into the complete response are , , and .

Note that impedance adds up like resistance in both series and parallel. You can also apply the voltage-current relationship (which is really just Ohm's law) to relate impedance to current and voltage.

Key concepts for chapter 10

To analyze an AC circuit:

  • Convert everything into the frequency domain. This means using impedance for capacitors, inductors and resistors. This also means finding phasors for any element as needed.
  • Use a strategy from previous chapters (nodal analysis, mesh analysis, basic KVL, etc.) to solve for what you need in the circuit. This will likely yield some answer in the frequency domain with complex number calculations involved.
  • Convert from the frequency domain to the time domain if needed.

Most of chapter 10 is simply getting used to the idea of the "frequency" domain, in which things start going into the complex plane, where numbers have a real and an imaginary part. But many previous strategies still work; you can still use KVL and KCL if you have phasors in terms of and respectively. (Just make sure everything is either in the time domain or in the frequency domain!) In turn, this means that things like mesh and node analysis still work, though with extra steps.

AC circuits have their voltage (and in turn, current) represented by a sinusoidal wave. We often convert voltage as a function of time into its equivalent phasor, which considerably simplifies any math we do with other phasors; then, we convert from the phasor back into a function in the time domain.

Working with phasors involves working with complex numbers. (You can see Complex numbers for an overview on them.) You should learn to figure out how to do polar and rectangular calculations on your calculator, as it will save quite a bit of time. But if you're doing it manually (or you need it in one specific form for some reason), you should know how to add/subtract/multiply/divide complex numbers, as well as how to convert between the two forms.

Remember that capacitors and inductors resist changes to voltage and current, respectively. So when the voltage and current is changing all the time in a sine wave, we're going to need to take a different approach to figure out their behavior in an AC circuit. This is where impedance comes in, and it's very similar to resistance in DC circuits. Capacitors, inductors, and resistors are all passive elements, and have some impedance to them in an AC circuit; they involve expressions in the complex plane, and each element has its own impedance expression.

Introduction
...

In general, AC sources are ubiquitous as general-purpose sources. These are the ones that come out of walls. However, most devices require DC - why not just use DC, then? The fact is that each device needs different input voltages, and the only way to vary your voltages in a DC circuit is to use voltage divider, where a bunch of power is lost through some resistor designed to "step down" the voltage to what the device needs.

But instead, we can use AC and a transformer, which simply uses a set of coils around a magnet to convert the AC voltage into a specified DC voltage. Since we know about magnetic flux and magnetic coils generating current, if we run the same magnetic flux through fewer coils, we can step down the voltage generated by the AC source into a DC source. This avoids needing to use a "burner" resistor for the purposes of stepping down voltages, and makes AC more efficient.

Sine waves
...

This chapter focuses on the use of sinusoidal AC sources, which is a periodic function defined by
which yield expressions for voltage and current:

where is the period, is the frequency in Hertz, and is the angular frequency equal to . (The definitions for period, amplitude, and frequency are identical to other periodic functions.)

Furthermore, for the voltage and current expressions, and refer to their amplitude (or maximum magnitude); is the phase shift in radians or degrees.

You may see excluded implicitly for sin waves that start exactly on time; that is, the sine wave is equal to 0 for . But for sine waves that start at 0 slightly earlier or later, then a phase shift exists. Positive phase shifts mean that the sine wave starts at 0 earlier than , and is referred to as leading. Negative phase shifts mean that the sine wave starts at 0 later than , and is referred to as lagging.

Of course, we can also refer to cosine as a sin wave with a phase shift of 90 degrees, or radians. So it holds that
and
and it also holds that a phase shift of 180 degrees on a shiftless sine wave is equivalent to . You can apply these facts to convert between cosine and sine waves as necessary.

If we plot the current and voltage functions, if the current function reaches its peak before the voltage function for , then we say that "current leads the voltage" or "voltage lags the current." You must ensure that you are comparing two sinusoidal waves (or waves of the same type).

and since we take the difference from the voltage, this means that voltage leads by 30 degrees. If we instead got a negative value here, this would indicate that voltage lags. Note that we are measuring relative to the voltage function; you can also take the difference , in which case positive values mean that the current leads and negative values mean that the current lags.

Phasors
...

To make our math easier, we will often convert everything to a frequency domain when analyzing AC circuits. This means that we convert from time to an expression in terms of .

To do this, we can use phasors, which allow us to convert to and to . The conditions for using a phasor are

  • the circuit must be linear
  • the steady-state response is sought (it can't be used for transient phase)
  • all independent sources are sinusoidal and have the same frequency

Of note is that when working with frequency domains, we jump from to , where everything will eventually end up as a complex number with a real and imaginary part.

We also drop the radian frequency , since we are only solving for one specific frequency - does not vary when using phasors, as per our initial conditions. In addition, since we are working in the frequency domain and not in the time domain, is also unused.

Finally, note that we typically choose the cosine function for phasor notation. This means you must convert any functions in terms of sine into their cosine equivalents.

If your calculator has the option to solve complex systems of equations, you should also learn how to do that as well. For example, an Nspire CAS requires you to use csolve() instead of the standard solve() or linsolve() functions to solve complex systems with a high degree of accuracy.

Impedance
...

In DC circuits, we can generally describe the relationship between voltage and current using resistance.

But how do we do the same for an AC circuit, when the current changes in phase shift after passing through some circuit element?

When the voltage and current are in phase, we can continue to express the relationship as resistance, given that no imaginary part exists.

But when the voltage and current are out of phase, there exists an imaginary part when taking , and so resistance no longer describes the relationship accurately, since resistance should not change as a function of time. Instead, we refer to this as impedance , which refers to the ratio of the phasor voltage to the phasor current.

Impedance in AC circuits has a similar role ot the role of resistance in DC circuits. Again, since we have a complex number that can be represented three different ways, there are several ways to directly evaluate for impedance.

Note that the real part of is resistance, and the imaginary part is reactance. What is reactance?

Recall that inductors and capacitors resist changes in voltage or current. Then, it turns out that a positive term for reactance (when is in rectangular form) is equivalent to an inductor, and a negative term for reactance is equivalent to a capcitor.

Note that an analogous expression to resistance and conductance is impedance and admittance. Admittance is equal to - that is, the reciprocal of impedance. It holds that the real part of admittance is conductance in Siemens, and the imaginary part is susceptance, where positive terms are capacitors and negative terms are inductors.

Impedance combinations
...

Note that impedance is very much analgous to resistance in that:

  • in series, impedance combines like series resistors (take the simple sum)
  • in parallel, impedance combines like parallel resistors (take the sum of their reciprocals, and then take the reciprocal of that)
  • in series, you can apply voltage division using
  • in parallel, you can apply current division using
